#Text=Abdullah H.
#Text=Abdur-Razzaq
#Text=Abdullah H. Abdur-Razzaq ( December 20 , 1931 – November 21 , 2014 ) was an African-American activist and Muslim known for being one of Malcolm X 's most trusted associates .
#Text=Born James Monroe King Warden , he was known as James 67X when he belonged to the Nation of Islam and James Shabazz in the years after he left the organization . [ 1 ]
#Text=Early life
#Text=James Monroe King Warden was born in Brooklyn , New York , and raised in the impoverished Morningside Heights neighborhood of Manhattan . [ 2 ]
#Text=He attended the Bronx High School of Science , from which he graduated with honors . [ 3 ]
#Text=He enrolled in the City College of New York but transferred to Lincoln University in Chester County , Pennsylvania , after a year . [ 2 ]
#Text=He soon left that school as well to join the Army .
#Text=Following his discharge , he returned to Lincoln and graduated with honors in English in 1958 . [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=He received a master 's degree from Columbia University . [ 1 ]
#Text=His work
#Text=Warden joined the Nation of Islam at Mosque No. 7 , on 102 West 116th Street in New York City , under Minister Malcolm X .
#Text=As was the custom among Nation of Islam members , he abandoned the surname of Warden as a vestige of chattel slavery and became the 67th James in Mosque No. 7 . [ 5 ]
#Text=By 1960 , [ 1 ] he had been promoted to lieutenant in the Fruit of Islam , subordinate to Captain Joseph X. Gravitt ( later known as Yusuf Shah ) . [ 6 ]
#Text=Subsequently , he was appointed circulation manager for New York , New Jersey , and Connecticut of Muhammad Speaks , and answered directly to Malcolm X.

#Text=After the split between Malcolm X and the Nation of Islam , Malcolm X formed Muslim Mosque , Inc. and appointed James , then still known as James 67X , secretary of the organization , as well as captain of the men .
#Text=Based on Malcolm X 's instruction , he took the name James Shabazz .

#Text=Brother James , as he was sometimes referred , was also responsible for the formation of the Organization of Afro-American Unity , a secular organization that Malcolm X had also formed , patterned after Addis Ababa , Ethiopia 's Organisation of African Unity , and through which Malcolm X intended to charge the United States with violating the human rights of its chattel slave descendants .
#Text=Shabazz was a constant and willing aide to Malcolm X , in his capacity as head of Muslim Mosque , Inc. [ 7 ] and as head of the Organization of Afro-American Unity .
#Text=He remained with , and vigorously assisted Malcolm X until the leader 's murder on February 21 , 1965 . [ 8 ]
#Text=Post-Malcolm X days

#Text=Abdur-Razzaq spent the years following Malcolm X 's murder raising a family and co-founding Al-Karim School ( which would later become Brooklyn 's famed Cush Campus Schools ) with Ora Abdur-Razzaq .
#Text=He later moved to Guyana , where he worked as a farmer .
#Text=Returning to the U.S. in 1988 , he earned a nursing degree , and he worked in as a nurse until his retirement in 2004 . [ 4 ]

#Text=In his later years , Abdur-Razzaq 's work as staff consultant for the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture was invaluable in cataloging rare photographs , letters and accounts of Malcolm X 's life and times .
#Text=Furthermore , his expertise was widely solicited by journalists , authors , film makers and educators .

#Text=In addition to his contributions to a wide array of published works , such as Bruce Perry 's Malcolm X : The Last Speeches , Abdur-Razzaq was featured in several television interviews and films , including Malcolm X : Make It Plain [ 9 ] and Gil Noble 's Like It Is .

#Text=The DVD version of Jack Baxter 's documentary Brother Minister : The Assassination of Malcolm X includes an " Exclusive Interview with Abdullah Abdur-Razzaq , Malcolm X 's closest associate " . [ 10 ]
#Text=Final years and death
#Text=In April 2013 , Abdur-Razzaq returned to Lincoln University to speak about his memories and experiences working with Malcolm X. [ 11 ] [ 2 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=Battling leukemia , Abdur-Razzaq was admitted to Harlem Hospital in late 2014 .
#Text=After several weeks , he was transferred to Bellevue Hospital Center , where he died on November 21 , 2014 , at the age of 82 . [ 3 ]
#Text=He is survived by children , grandchildren , and a large extended family . [ 12 ]
